text: When you're browsing a repo on GitHub, pressing the [t] key will open up a search box and allow you to search for any file within the repo that you can then navigate to. This saves a ton of clicks especially when trying to find a file that's in a deeply-nested directory! Cool, right?
Typing [g i] will bring you directly to all of your GitHub issues. Same with [g p] for pull requests! Gnarly!
Create your own aliases in your [.gitconfig] file, so you don't need to type long command lines. Show others how to deploy with a simple [>git deploy]!
Use [>git stash] to quickly revert your changes. You can access them later using [git stash list], and you can even convert them into a branch using [>git stash branch]!
Use [>git log --graph] for a quick overview of the project branch history.
If you need to keep changes but you don't want to commit them, use [>git update-index --assume-unchanged YOURFILE] and Git will ignore them!

If you've made a typo in a command you haven't yet run, you can use [ctrl + a] to jump the cursor to the beginning of the command. [ctrl + e] will jump the cursor to the end. [option + click] will bring the cursor to wherever you clicked!
Use the [UP arrow] to cycle through previously run commands. This is useful when you're doing repetitive tasks like pushing commits to GitHub!
Use [ctrl + l] to clear the screen. This doesn't lose any of your previous commands, but can help if you need a visual break! Neat, huh?
Use [!!] to repeat your previous command. Because we love repeating ourselves right?
Hold down the [option] while scrolling forward or backwards for lightning fast speeds!
Use [cmd + number] to access the tab corresponding to the number. For example, to quicky switch to the third tab use [cmd + 3].
Use [history | grep <search term>] to search your history for a particular command. For example, [history | grep npm] to find all commands you've used that match npm.
[cmd + tab] will help you qickly cycle through your open applications instead of having to click on them from the dock. So fast!
[cmd + w] will close the current tab in most applications, now you can quicky close the 14/30 tabs you don't need in Chrome.
[cmd + q] will close the current application -- maybe you don't need any of those tabs!
You can use the [.editorconfig] format to maintain consistent coding styles between different editors and IDEs. Excellent if you are working in a group!
Everyone makes mistakes, keep yours in sight using a proper linting plugin. Don't be the one that forgot that ';'!
